lead_paragraph: UNDERHILL--Jacob Berry, III, retired president and director of the New York Life Insurance Company, a former journalist and New York State government official, died February 20, 2016 in New York after complications from esophageal cancer. He was 89. Born in New York City on October 25, 1926, the son of J. Berry Underhill, Jr. and Dorothy Quinn Underhill, he grew up in Greenwich, CT where he attended the Brunswick School. On graduation from the Phillips Exeter Academy in 1944, he enlisted at 17 in the United States Navy from which he was discharged as an electronics technician's mate, third class, following World War II. He attended Princeton University, graduating in 1950 with a degree in English and American Civilization. Underhill became editor of the Potsdam (New York) Courier and Freeman and later was legislative correspondent and political writer for the Rochester (New York) Democrat and Chronicle and the Gannett News Service Albany Bureau. He became chief editorial writer of the St. Petersburg Times (Florida) in 1956, and returned to New York City in 1959 as a magazine editor for the McGraw-Hill Publishing Company and later as a national affairs writer for Newsweek. In 1964, he joined the staff of Governor Nelson A. Rockefeller as an assistant press secretary. He was deputy superintendent and later first deputy superintendent of insurance for the State of New York, 1968-1972. Underhill joined New York Life in 1972, rising to president and director of the mutual life insurance company before retirement in 1986. At his death he maintained residences in Cocoa, FL and Antigua, West Indies. He was married four times, first to the late Cynthia Lovejoy Underhill, a teacher and newspaper editor, from whom he was divorced. He is survived by their three children, David L. Underhill of Portsmouth, NH, Kate Underhill Kerwin of Naples, FL and Benedict Q. Underhill of Brattleboro, VT, and six grandchildren, Graeme Underhill of Raymond, NH, Meaghan Kerwin of Sugar Grove, NC, Sean Kerwin of Culver City, CA, Jeff John of Brighton, MA, Meghan John of Keene, NH and Chris John of Brattleboro, VT. His second marriage, also terminated by divorce, was to Lois Beachy Underhill, an advertising executive and writer. His third wife was Betsy Finley Ashton, a television producer and reporter; they were divorced in 2007, and Underhill married Nancy McDonnell Maloney of Rockledge, FL, on June 5, 2007. Nancy Maloney was a practicing lawyer for 25 years. Elected in November of 2014, she now serves as Circuit Judge for the 18th Judicial Circuit in the State of Florida. A brother, Martin Quinn Underhill, predeceased him. Underhill was an emeritus trustee of the National Trust for Historic Preservation; honorary chairman of the Manhattan Eye, Ear and Throat Hospital; former chairman of the Better Business Bureau of Metropolitan New York; former chairman of the Life Insurance Council of New York; former trustee of the Retirement System of the American Red Cross; former director of the Health Insurance Association of America; United Way of Tri-State, and United Way of New York City. He was a member of The Players and The Links clubs of New York City, the Mill Reef Club of Antigua, West Indies, and the Legislative Correspondents Alumni Association of New York State. A memorial service will be arranged at a later date, with private burial. The family asks that memorial contributions may be made to the E.S. Wells Kerr 1944 Scholarship Fund, at Phillips Exeter Academy, Exeter, NH 03833. 1/3
